http://groups.yahoo.com/group/cgiwrap/message/1407

and even in its own man page :

http://httpd.apache.org/docs/mod/mod_alias.html#scriptaliasmatch
       

The problem is that we have .htaccess in the directory and it won't abide by
them. If we change to a combination of "ScriptAlias" and "Location /cgi-bin with
an Action and SetHandler (This is for CGIWRAP)" we have it abide by the
.htaccess.

text:
You haven't given enough configuration detail to figure out what is
happening, but the most likely problem is an AllowOverride setting.

I suggest you try addressing this problem on a user support group
before bringing it to the bug database.

What other information is necessary? If I switch between the 

ScriptAliasMatch ^/lcgi-bin/(.*)$ /usr/local/bin/cgiwrap/wraptest/lcgi-bin/$1

directive (Which I don't get it to prompt for authentication) and 

<Location /lcgi-bin>
Action cgi-wrapper /cgi-bin/cgiwrap/wraptest
SetHandler cgi-wrapper
</Location>

Which I do.
creator: apache@t-b-o-h.com
slive@apache.org
text:
In the ScriptAlias case, Apache never touches anything in the lcgi-bin directory.
Only cgiwrap even knows the true location of the cgi script (because it is
passed in PATH_INFO).  Therefore the .htaccess file in lcgi-bin is never applied.
For the same reason, if you have "Alias /foo /bar", if there happens to
be a real directory named "/foo" under the DocumentRoot, its .htaccess
file will NOT be applied.  The .htaccess file in /bar will be applied instead.

In the Action/SetHandler case, Apache knows that a file in lcgi-bin will be 
processed, and it therefore applies the .htaccess in that directory. 

In the future, please follow the instructions on the bug submission pages
and address your configuration questions on a user-support forum before
bringing them to the bug database.

Thanks for using Apache!
